text: , also Empo, was a after Kanbun and before Tenna. This period started in September 1673 and ended in September 1681.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Empo" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 176. During this time, the reigning emperor was .Nussbaum, "Reigen Tennō," p. 785; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 414-415. == Events of the Enpō era == * 1673 (Enpō 1): A great fire destroyed much of Heian-kyō.Titsingh, p. 414. * 1673 (Enpō 1): Mitsui opened a dry goods store in Edo.Hall, John Whitney. (1970). Japan: From Prehistory to Modern Times, p. 209. * 10 May 1674 (Enpō 2, 5th day of the 4th month): Ingen died at Mampuku-ji near Heian-kyō. * 1675 (Enpō 3): A great fire in Heian-kyō. * 1675 (Enpō 3): The Bonin Islands are explored by shogunate.Tanaka, Hiroyuki. (1993). "The Ogasawara Islands in Tokugawa Japan", Kaiji Shi Kenkyuu (Journal of the Maritime History). * 7 April 1680 (Enpō 8, 8th day of the 3rd month) : Tokugawa Ietsuna died. * 11 September 1680 (Enpō 8, 19th day of the 8th month): Former-Emperor Go-Mizunoo died.Titsingh, p. 414; Meyer, Eva-Maria. (1999). Japans Kaiserhof in der Edo-Zeit, p. 186; Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), 後水尾天皇 (108); retrieved 2012-5-27. ==Related pages == * Edo period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Enpō 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th 1673 1674 1675 1676 1677 1678 1679 1680 1681 Preceded by: Kanbun Era or nengō: Enpō Succeeded by: Tenna Category:Japanese eras Category:1673 establishments Category:17th- century establishments in Japan Category:1680s disestablishments in Japan
title: Enpō
